content.description: This one is all about the crux but that one move feels great to pull!  Start as for Creature Comforts, clipping the first bolt and then moving up and left past another bolt to the roof.  You guessed it  pulling the roof is the crux.  This one looks intimidating but the holds are bomb and the move is easier than it looks, and well-protected.  Above the roof, easy climbing gains the two bolt anchor.  Walk off left to descend.
content.location: This begins on the first bolt line on the far left end of the wall.

content.description: Start up the face just left of the far right edge of the Main Wall - Left. Continue up sloping edge holds angling left past 2 bolts to the top.
content.protection: 2 Bolts, no anchor. Sling rocks on top or use the bolts on Hands Off The Crack (too far left for comfortable TR)
content.location: Farthest right route on the Main Wall - Left. Left angling edge/semi-arete/layback.

content.description: The leftmost crack on the headwall
content.protection: no bolts, good pro. Same anchors as Weak Sister.
content.location: Leftmost climb. Start with the undercling lieback up to the obvious cracks.

content.description: Maybe size doesnt matter.  This one is short, even for this wall, but oh so very sweet.  LJS is the first bolted line just right of the roof area.  It is fairly sustained on 5.9  5.10a crimps.  This is what this wall is all about!  Hard to say exactly where the crux is but I felt it was the last move to gain the anchors.  Great climb for the grade.  Walk off right to descend.

Very sustained on small crimpers and vertical rock; arguably harder than the original rating, at least 5.10c in my opinion. But a very fun climb that will keep you on your toes, both literally and mentally. Very difficult stances for clipping.
content.location: This one climbs the thin face between the cracks on the right side of Main Wall Left and is probably the best route on this wall.

content.description: This is the bolt line just left of the zig zag cracks and right of Evil Eye.  Work your way up past the horizontal crack.  Crimps and small ledges take you up past two bolts to the anchor.  A small cam about .5 can be used in the horizontal as the first bolt is pretty high.  Another nice crimpy face climb but at an easier grade.  Walk off right to descend.

Climb the central pillar of the lesser wall, formed by the two deep hand cracks.  This climb uses a combination of face holds, smearing and jamming.  The crux is the set of finishing moves, which can too easily be avoided.  This route does not have a set of anchors but can be TRd from the anchor for Cavity Search  be aware of the possibility for a nasty swing if you fall.  Garbage Can could also be done as a lead on gear but works best as a highball.  Walk to the left or right, then descend the easy chimney to the base.

This is a link-up that starts on

Good Son

and then moves left to finish with the upper portion of

Evil Eye

.
Traverse left to right across the horizontal crack. 10-15 feet the whole time. End at Broken Heart
content.location: start with a scramble up left, slabby direct, or undercling/layback up right to get into the main crack traverse that starts under the shrub/Noteworthy crack.

content.description:
Another nice, fairly sustained route on thin edges with a start similar to LJS. Passing the second, or bulging, eye is most likely the crux and affords an interesting problem to be solved. I rate it here as 5.9 only out of respect to the FA team.

I thought Evil Eye was harder than anything on LJS and would rate it at 5.10b. Great climb!
content.location:
Climbs the bolt line just right of

Little Jerry Seinfeld

.

content.description: Devil Man climbs up across the obvious zig zag cracks in the center of the wall.  A nice moderate mix of face and crack climbing with good pro, and a brief respite from the other routes for your fingertips!.  Fun TR if you forgot to bring the trad gear.  Walk off right to descend.
Just right of the Devil Man zigzag cracks. Over the undercling, then a up the thin crack to the large curving left facing offwidth crack.
content.protection: Light rack, small nuts and cams up to 3 inches.
content.location: Look for the large curving crack near the rigth end of the wall. Route is between Devil Man and Hands off the Crack. Walk off (right) is easiest descent.

content.description: Straightforward bolted route on sharp cornflake crimps. Crux is near the top.

On the lesser wall of Main Wall Left, climb just right of the central pillar on easy holds, up the thin seam to the horizontal.  The crux is moving up right from the horizontal to the anchor.  Can also be done as a lead on gear but there is no good stance for clipping the anchor.  Walk to the left or right, then descend the easy chimney to the base.

Start on the left side of the lesser wall, behind the northeast arete of the left Main Wall, below the thin seam.  Work up using fine balance on tiny crimps, to the good side-pulls half-way up.  Past this section the climb finishes on larger holds.  Walk to the left or right, then descend the easy chimney to the base.

This is the obvious left-leaning crack to the right of Hands Off the Crack, and shares the same anchor.  Start in the lower right-tending crack.  The crux is getting established in the left-leaning crack.  Pro here is very thin but not unreasonable.  Follow the crack as it widens from fingertips to good hands with great pro.  Very fun moderate crack and yet another rest for those throbbing fingertips.  Walk off right to descend.

This is the second bolt line from the left.  Start on small crimps and work straight up to the roof.  This one is a bit contrived  moving a couple feet to the right at this point yields a much easier move over the roof and down-rates the climb to about 5.10a, making the lower crimps the crux of the climb.  The true crux involves an unlikely move on good crimps with no feet over the bulge, leading to feet with no hands still short of the anchor  harder than 5.11a in my opinion.  Walk off left to descend.

This one starts on thin but easy holds on the right side of the lesser wall, below a big bush growing out of a seam.  Climb up past a seam to the left of the bush, to the horizontal.  Finish up and left to the anchor.  Climbing to the horizontal felt easier than 5.7; the crux is getting from the horizontal to the anchor and feels harder than 5.7, possibly as hard as the crux move on Cookie Monster.  Walk to the left or right, then descend the easy chimney to the base.
